choices.C: The registration key is missing from the command
choices.A: DONOTRESOLVE must be added to the command
choices.B: The IP address used should be that of the Cisco FTD, not the Cisco FMC
choices.D: The NAT ID is required since the Cisco FMC is behind a NAT device

questions.question_text: An engineer is using the configure manager add Cisc404225383 command to add a new Cisco FTD device to the Cisco FMC; however, the device is not being added. Why is this occurring?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The NAT ID is required since the Cisco FMC is behind a NAT device
command line in FTD :configure manager add <FMC ip> <key> <NAT-ID>,NAT-ID is optional.

"If the FMC is behind a NAT device, enter a unique NAT ID along with the registration key, and specify DONTRESOLVE instead of the hostname, for example:

Example:
> configure manager add DONTRESOLVE regk3y78 natid90
Manager successfully configured.

If the FTD is behind a NAT device, enter a unique NAT ID along with the FMC IP address or hostname, for example:

Example:
> configure manager add 10.70.45.5 regk3y78 natid56
Manager successfully configured. "
Reference: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/640/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v64/device_management_basics.html

So, according to this phrase from the cisco material, answer C seems to make more sense due to the fact that if DONTRESOLVE is missing then a NAT_ID is for sure required as well, so both of them are missing. Since we have only one option, it is more likely that the reg_key is missing, in my opinion.
Whwre did the question state that its behind the NAT device? I go with Missing Registration key

The question is wrong , it should be "An engineer is using the configure manager add <FMC IP> Cisc404225383 command to add a new Cisco FTD device to the Cisco FMC; however, the device is not being added. Why is this occurring?"
Than "D " makes sense.

C is the correct answer. When registering the sensor to a Firepower Management Center, a unique
alphanumeric registration key is always required. In most cases, to register
a sensor to a Firepower Management Center, you must provide the hostname or
the IP address along with the registration key.
'configure manager add [hostname | ip address ] [registration key ]'

I pick C. How do you know Cisc404225383 is not the hostname? the question only shows 1 item listed after the manager add base command. if that is the Nat_ID then we are missing the IP or DONTRESOLVE & reg key.

Step 5 Configure the new FMC.
configure manager add {hostname | IPv4_address | IPv6_address | DONTRESOLVE } regkey [nat_id]

{hostname | IPv4_address | IPv6_address}—Sets the FMC hostname, IPv4 address, or IPv6 address.

DONTRESOLVE — If the FMC is not directly addressable, use DONTRESOLVE instead of a hostname or IP address. If you use DONTRESOLVE , then a nat_id is required. When you add this device to the FMC, make sure that you specify both the device IP address and the nat_id ; one side of the connection needs to specify an IP address, and both sides need to specify the same, unique NAT ID.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/610/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v61/device_management_basics.html

comments.content:
I completely agree, reg_key is required but nat_id is not.
If Cisc404225383 is the host name, then all that is missing is the reg_key.
If Cisc404225383 is the reg_key, then the hostname or IP is missing to begin with, but that is not an option.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
configure manager add {hostname | IPv4_address | IPv6_address | DONTRESOLVE } regkey [nat_id]

Selected Answer: A
wrong answer, apparently the registration key and NAT ID is present and what's missing is either the FMC IP address or the DONOTRESOLVE key word before registration key, so that the FTD will actually register to any FMC provides this registration key and NAT ID regardless to the FMC IP

Selected Answer: C
You have to type in the registration key

questions.question_text: An organization does not want to use the default Cisco Firepower block page when blocking HTTP traffic. The organization wants to include information about its policies and procedures to help educate the users whenever a block occurs. Which two steps must be taken to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C and D

Selected Answer: CD
https://community.cisco.com/t5/network-security/access-control-policy-block-response-page/td-p/2570606

https://www.wiresandwi.fi/blog/firepower-url-blocking-page-setup-and-management#:~:text=Configuring%20Block%20and%20Interactive%20Page&text=Log%20into%20your%20FMC%20and,the%20policy%20of%20your%20choice.
C&D-- You change the response page to custom (for both types) and then you choose the edit pencil to upload your "HTML CODE"

questions.question_text: A company has many Cisco FTD devices managed by a Cisco FMC. The security model requires that access control rule logs be collected for analysis. The security engineer is concerned that the Cisco FMC will not be able to process the volume of logging that will be generated. Which configuration addresses concern this?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. From attended Cisco training. Connection to SIEM, Security in FMC.

Selected Answer: A
From Cisco Official course :

If you need to log all traffic information for compliance, you can uncheck Firewall Management Center as a logging destination and just leave the Syslog Server option. This configuration will free up a lot of resources on the FMC as the syslog is being generated directly from the managed device.

This probably confirms the answer A
The FMC can log some syslogs. However, it does not have adequate storage provision to accommodate voluminous information from connection events.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/secure-firewall/management-center/device-config/710/management-center-device-config-71/interfaces-settings-platform.html#task_88952FB807AB4D43B0894F99B215EDD4:~:text=The%20FMC%20can%20log%20some%20syslogs.%20However%2C%20it%20does%20not%20have%20adequate%20storage%20provision%20to%20accommodate%20voluminous%20information%20from%20connection%20events

my answer is "D". FTD events should be delivered to FMC first and forward to SIEM. so FMC can do analysis itself first before any information is forwarded. FMC storage data can be purged due to a limited storage space. we are using Splunk forwarder as SIEM. FMC is receiving all event and security incidents and forwarding to Splunk for further analysis.

Selected Answer: B
A does not make any sense to me, the SIEM would have duplicate logs.
You can configure FTD to send the ACP logs directly via syslog.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GjKavkRbUVg

comments.content:
If the FMC cannot handle the load, A makes no sense. 
Also, in the ACP, you can just decide to log to FMC, Syslog, or both. 
Direct Syslog is the only thing that makes sense for me here. I go with the original answer.
I looked for configurations where FTD pushes the logs directly towards a SIEM and I could not find any. It seems the only way is FTD>FMC>SIEM. I could be wrong tho

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I think A is the best practices.

https://panenka.sk/cisco-fmc-ftd-eventing/#:~:text=FTD%20firewall%20will%20send%20syslogs,still%20delivered%20to%20the%20FMC.

choices.A: Send Cisco FTD connection events directly to a SIEM system and forward security events from Cisco FMC to the SIEM system for storage and analysis
choices.D: Send Cisco FTD connection events and security events to Cisco FMC and configure it to forward logs to SIEM for storage and analysis
choices.C: Send Cisco FTD connection events and security events to a cluster of Cisco FMC devices for storage and analysis
choices.B: Send Cisco FTD connection events and security events directly to SIEM system for storage and analysis

choices.A: Only Spero file analysis is enabled.
choices.D: The malware license has not been applied to the Cisco FTD.
choices.C: A file policy has not been applied to the access policy.
choices.B: The Cisco FMC cannot reach the Internet to analyze files.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
B- wrong - it'd be unavailable
C/D - wrong - otherwise exe wouldn't get caught

A is the answer. 

First Time File Analysis: Determines what to do when you see a file for the first time. This likely means that the file has not been seen on the internet before, and so its disposition is unknown. Most new files will be clean, but you can send them to the ThreatGRID® Cloud for analysis, to increase global awareness, and our own. The file must match a rule configured to perform a malware cloud lookup and Spero, local malware, or dynamic analysis. If you disable this option, files detected for the first time are marked with an Unknown disposition.
First Time File Analysis: Determines what to do when you see a file for the first time. This likely means that the file has not been seen on the internet before, and so its disposition is unknown. Most new files will be clean, but you can send them to the ThreatGRID® Cloud for analysis, to increase global awareness, and our own. The file must match a rule configured to perform a malware cloud lookup and Spero, local malware, or dynamic analysis. 
If you disable this option, files detected for the first time are marked with an Unknown disposition.

I believe answer is A.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/623/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v623/file_policies_and_advanced_malware_protection.html

questions.question_text: A network administrator reviews the file report for the last month and notices that all file types, except exe, show a disposition of unknown. What is the cause of this issue?
An engineer is configuring a Cisco FTD appliance in IPS-only mode and needs to utilize fail-to-wire interfaces. Which interface mode should be used to meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Yes, D is correct

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is:

D. inline set

In IPS-only mode, using an inline set allows the Cisco FTD appliance to act as a bump on the wire, binding two interfaces together to transparently pass traffic while providing intrusion prevention capabilities. This setup supports fail-to-wire interfaces, ensuring traffic continues to flow even if the appliance fails
Never mind, routed is an interface type.
Straight out the gate you can eliminate Routed & Transparent since those are FTD Deployment modes Not interfaces modes.

D. inline set.

When configuring a Cisco FTD appliance in IPS-only mode and utilizing fail-to-wire interfaces, the inline set interface mode should be used. This mode allows the device to inspect traffic and take action on it inline without disrupting traffic flow. The transparent mode allows the FTD to operate as a Layer 2 bridge, while the routed mode operates at Layer 3. The passive mode allows the FTD to monitor traffic without taking any action on it.

Selected Answer: D
Fail-to-wire interfaces are used for bypassing traffic around an FTD appliance during a failure, and can only be used with the inline set interface mode. Therefore, the correct answer is D, inline set.

Selected Answer: D
Transparent is not an interface mode, inline set is
